reviewText:
Isn't it strange when you come across a mobile game that doesn't actually suck... but is instead fun and challenging? That's what my experience with Hitman GO was like.

I vividly remember playing Hitman: Absolution a few years ago and feeling like the guy from this Youtube clip: $https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=31g0YE61PLQ (you'll have to copy and paste the url without the $ at the start because embedded Youtube videos tend to freeze the Steam client). Ok, it wasn't that bad. But while both Hitman: Absolution and Hitman GO are not true Hitman games... the latter's better for it. Unlike Hitman: Absolution, Hitman GO is a solid title that confidently knows what it wants to be and because of this it can stand strong on its own two feet.


Hitman GO is very much a puzzle game at its core. Each map resembles a typical game board filled with pieces. The player controls the Agent 47 piece and the ultimate objective is to reach the marked destination point (or assassination target on some rare levels) using whatever's placed on the map to your advantage (distraction objects, disguises and so on). The player always starts first and has to make their move. Afterwards, every other piece on the board gets to make their move and then it's back to the player to make their move again. It might sound simple but this turn-based game does get challenging once the player passes the early levels and new enemies start getting introduced.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=631897125

Speaking of levels, there's 15 in each chapter (or game box) and 4 main chapters. A further 2 bonus chapters are supposedly inspired by levels Curtains Down" and "St. Petersburg Stakeout" which come from games Hitman: Blood Money and Hitman 2: Silent Assassin respectively
date: and there's yet another bonus chapter called "Airport". So that all adds up to 91 levels (since the Hitman-inspired chapters only have 8 levels each). Truth be told I've only played a little past the first chapter but I'm really enjoying what I have played so far. Each level has a set of 3 objectives
recommended: and 2 of them are always different
hoursPlayed: so it's likely the player will be revisiting each level more than once. On top of that
voteText:
most players will want to see if they can beat each level again in less moves so the replayability's there.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=631897409

The game doesn't look fancy graphically but that's completely fine because it does its job. It looks just fine on my PC and I'm especially fond of the 3d sets. There's no story but I didn't expect there to be one. The game has a lovely theme that plays on the main menu and level selection screen -- it's calm
helpfulPercent: soft and appropriate for a thinking game such as this one. There's not much music for the levels themselves (mostly ambient or background noise) but Ave Maria did play on one of the levels and I couldn't help but stop and listen. For those of you who are not familiar with the song
votesHelpful: it was the main theme for Hitman: Blood Money. Fantastic choice.\n\nAs for the port itself: it's nothing extraordinary but performance and everything the player would expect out of a game like this is perfectly satisfactory. I could do with a little more options though (since the Options menu is currently very limited and I know some might not like that). Apart from that
votesTotal: the Steam achievements seem to be bugged at the moment (seeing as though I and several people on the game's Community Hub haven't got any achievements whatsoever) and other than the minor facelift this game's received as well as the removal of in-app purchases
votesFunny:
there's not much difference between the mobile version and this "Definitive Edition".
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=631896498

Overall this is one of those rare mobile games that I can recommend and thus I strongly suggest you consider purchasing. By supporting a good spin-off game like Hitman GO
commentsCount: you'll be sending a message to Square Enix that games like this are what we expect of them and not anything else. I only hope the newest Hitman game will end up being this good. For all of this
column20: 138 of 165 people (84%) found this review helpful 6 people found this review funny

reviewText:
A succeeded puzzle-game for every now and then

Gameplay Hitman go is an initially easy, turn-based strategy game, but it becomes sophisticated very quickly, forcing even experienced puzzlers to think.

You have to get past different guards to reach a target, which you then usually assassinate. For me, the controls were well designed and you only need the left mousebutton. The levels are held in a graphically simple diorama style, and it's this simplistic gameplay and graphics that make the game so interesting for me. It is perfect to play for 1-3 hours every now and then.

I got a beta key from the publisher but I tested the final version.

Pros:  The music is amazing. Songs like Ave Maria give the song its vibe.
Simple controls, good pc port and challenging puzzles
Good price
Steamcloud &. Steamachievements
Cons:  The graphics
A workshop would be great

Conclusion:
Hitman go is a succeeded variation for every now and then. I don't often play puzzle games, but I truly enjoyed this one with its minimalistic but challenging way. I can only recommend trying it out, since it's also cheap.

Total rating: 7/10


If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

reviewText:
Hitman GO is a very simplistic but rewarding game. This is the definitive PC version of a mobile game.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GDXIeVLmV4g
I'll start off with the PC port details.
You don't have control over advanced graphical options like texture detail or shadows, but I think this game can get away with it considering its simplistic look. It still looks great though! You can change resolution, fullscreen and vsync, and that's about it.

The PC version has also gotten rid of any microtransactions, and we've been given all DLC bonus levels in this one package.

Now onto the game itself.
Your goal in every level is to get to the exit. Sometimes, that will require you to kill guards on the way there. Eventually, in certain levels you will need to take out a target.
The game is turnbased, so nothing moves until you do. Some guards are stationary, while others will move forward after your move.

The game does a good job at keeping the experience varied. You get objects to throw and distract guards with, or bushes to hide in, as well as trap doors to teleport" through. Guard types react differently to eachother
date: and each chapter has its own location and theme.\n\nEach level gives you what I'm going to call "Hitman Tokens"
recommended: that you can spend on buying the next chapter. So if you get stuck on the current chapter you're on
hoursPlayed: you are free to skip to the next one. You may also earn bonus tokens by completing certain challenges within a level. This adds replay value. Sometimes you'll be tasked to complete a level killing no one
voteText: killing everyone
votesHelpful: or doing it in a certain amount of moves.\n\nThe game can be quite challenging
votesTotal: but that makes it that much more rewarding.\n\nOverall
votesFunny: I really enjoy the game. It's a cool new way of playing in the Hitman universe
commentsCount: that feels faithful although different enough. My only problem is I haven't figured out a way to move around without swiping. It's not a huge problem
column16: but I would have liked the option to click on the next tile
column18: loads of fun and simple enough to get into
column19: but will definitely make you tear your hair out later on. (In a good way)\n"

I read some of the negative reviews because, well i was wondering what someone thought was negative about this game.
Some said it didn't play on PC...plays on mine just fine. Some complained that their weren't enough settings...for what? The game doen't need any. Some said too expensive...really? I pay more to see a two hour movie. Some said it doesn't feel like the other Hitman game...surprise...it isn't, did you even look at the video or pictures? Talk about peas under matresses.

In my opinion this game is fun and quick. I can play a fast board or several. I didn't expect anything more then what was advertised and I am very happy with what I recieved.

reviewText:
Really interesting game, Fun and intriguing puzzles, but this is the most bare-bones Janky PC port ever.

Complaints that need to be addressed before I can possibly consider a positive recommendation of this game:

Volume Sliders for Music and Sound Effects, current options are on" and "off"

Re-mappable controls. Are you kidding me
date: I can't change the default controls in 2016.\n\nTurn off "auto-camera recenter" Some of the levels can be hard to see because they are complex and start you off at weird angles
recommended: for some reason I can "turn the camera" to see the level from a different angle
hoursPlayed: but if I let go of turn
voteText: the camera goes back to the default position
helpfulPercent: instead of staying where I moved it
votesHelpful: this is especially frustrating because which direction "up
commentsCount: right"  move Agent 47 is dependent on what angle you are viewing him at
column16: this can cause you to move him the wrong direction accidentally due to a camera shift. These are PlayStation 1 tomb-raider/resident evil levels of camera control fail.\n\nNo options in pause menu. You pause the game
column17: and your available selections are "cancel" by which they mean "resume" "restart" which actually does what it says
column18: and "Quit" which actually just returns you to the level select screen. No OPTIONS menu in the pause menu?! Am I taking crazy pills!?\n\nGame has no level creator mode
column19: and is not on steam workshop. Are you kidding me? A game this simple and generic and you don't have options for the community to make custom levels? Morons

reviewText: This is a fantastic game.  I found it very addictive.  This game consists of short little puzzles challenging you to get Agent 47 through levels filled with guards, briefcases to collect, and targets to kill".  The game plays out like a board game with chess-like pieces.  New pieces (both enemy and support for Agent 47) and new mechanics are slowly introduced over the game's missions.\n\nThis is probably the first mobile game I've really played.  I do have a smart phone and a tablet
date: but I have virtually never use those for gaming.  I was reluctant to try this game out because of it's mobile roots
recommended: but watching a Twitch stream changed my mind.  It seemed like a lot of fun.  I was not disappointed.  I'm glad it came to PC.\n\nThe game is played with the mouse only
hoursPlayed: swiping Agent 47 to the direction you want him to go.  I would definitely have appreciated a single click option.  There's no keyboard support but I don't think that's a big deal for a game like this.\n\nI do think it's unfortunate that a level editor of some sort wasn't created for this release (as suggested by other reviewers).  It would have been pretty awesome if the community could have built more levels.  The game is a bit short.  It took me about 6 hrs to complete (totally worth the $6 and some change I paid).  I was good enough that I want more."

reviewText: A superb puzzle game with pleasing simple graphics and Hitman™ theme (which I'm glad of, because I would have missed this otherwise as I'm not usually a big puzzle fan). It took me almost 8 hours to complete the game with all achievements and with zero hints before the last achievement, money well spent. Various rewarding experiences when you finally finish all the objectives when fighting against the trickier levels.\n\nI didn't notice problems or difficulties at all, except that I couldn't get achievements while playing windowed, but that's only a minor thing. If you crave for quality puzzles without feeling like emptying your wallet drastically, buy HItman GO immediately. For a Hitman fan this is also something to consider, even if you're like me who often lacks patience for even mildly harder puzzles.

reviewText:
Fun little game that is basically a board game or puzzle that requires some thinking and planning. Its fairly relaxing and adds some features as you proceed like different enemies, covert uniforms, rocks to alter guards paths, bushes to hide in and even a gun to pick off someone you select.  Its fairly basic, but for a tablet to pc for a decent price is worth a few hours of gameplay.

The game has 7 levels, most have 15 little missions each, except for 1 that has 8. That is approximately 100 total. Some will take several attempts so its likely good for 6-10 hours.

I just beat it, most boards with 2 of 3 stars. Could certainly get many more hours if I wanted to get all 3 stars on each board. The stars vary from collecting the suitcase, killing all enemies, not killing any enemies, not killing dogs or using under so many moves/turns. Some will take repeating a level to get all three stars.


+Nice simple graphics
+Good puzzles that progress
+Good saving system and challenges that escalate
+Good appetizer, although completely different than the real Hitman release in a couple of weeks.

Wish you got a free copy of this if pre-ordered the main title as I did, since we have to wait throughout the year for a many of the levels to be completed periodically. Obviously don't get this if you don't like puzzles and are expecting a traditional Hitman game.

reviewText: A fun game, but the port is severely lacking. It doesn't seem to support keyboard use at all; you must click-and-drag with a mouse in imitation of the original touch controls even though the can-only-move-in-four-directions design is ideally suited to WASD/arrow key use.\n\nAlso, the Steam Achievements are very buggy (aren't achievable). This problem is widespread and longstanding, but the developers haven't addressed it at all. I'm a huge Hitman fan and I'd like to recommend this game, but while two serious deficiencies linger like this (indicating that the developers don't care to support their product), I can't.

reviewText:
So the critically acclaimed Hitman GO gets a long overdue port from mobile platforms to PC and console with this - the Hitman GO: Definitive Edition. (Though the truth is we are probably only getting it now to help build up hype and garner more press coverage ahead of the AAA reboot in a couple of weeks time.)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kvRnvQ6T64s

As ports go it's not a bad one. The game runs really smoothly. And I didn't notice any major bugs or errors or anything like that.

Admittedly having to actually drag Agent 47 a tile at a time using the mouse feels a little odd at first (as your instinct is to point and click at where you want him to go) but you do get used to it. And as cute as the art style is there are occassionally moments when you can see some of the textures don't really upscale that well from the smaller screen of the iPad to a larger monitor. But these are just minor niggles.

At the end of the day this is a really satisfying little strategy/puzzle game and definitely worth checking out. And is probably a must buy just as soon as it hits that first Steam sale and gets 40-50% knocked off the price to bring it in line with the iOS and Android versions.

reviewText:
Hitman GO beautifully encapsulates the Hitman experience all whilst switching the genre to a turn-based strategy game. Previously on mobile, with fantastic art style, ambient music and absolutely lovely environments inspired by physical board games and dioramas that look even better in higher resolutions, GO is still a game I adore.

It uses all classic Hitman gameplay mechanics, such as disguises, timing your movement, learning enemy pathings, hiding in plain sight (here with help of a plant), sniper rifles and of course, 47's trusted Silverballers and mixes them up to create an enthralling little title that's both easy to get the hang of and difficult to master. Hey, it's just like the regular Hitman games!

GO starts easy and slowly introduces more gameplay mechanics to the mix, ramping up the difficulty. The game is never too easy or too hard and even though I finished it multiple times on my Android device, I still have trouble with some challenges.

Unfortunatelly, the only problem I had with this game is still present in this version - the challenges are uninspired, usually consisting of picking up the briefcase or finishing the board in a set amount of turns. In most cases, those challenges also cancel each other out (in most cases, you cannot waste turns on the briefcase when you're trying to finish the level fast) therefore, for hitting that 100%, you will have to finish the levels multiple times.

The boards are never as long for it to become a hassle though and coming up with different strategies for different challenges starts feeling desirable as the game piles up its mechanics.

I never found it frustrating or cheap, the difficulty curve is perfect and I would totally recommend this game for everybody. Not just Hitman fans, but also puzzle game enthusiasts.

reviewText:
Been playing for about 90 min and have so far completed 2 boxes.

+ Artstyle - love it
+ Soundtrack - Hitman vibes
+ Full controller support
+ Well balanced puzzles (starts off very simple but increases in complexity at a slow, steady pace)
+ A surpringly high level of variety

- Less fortunate camera angles at times, especially if you have a 24 screen like myself. You can move your view around but it goes back to the center automatically when you let go...
- No way of adjusting much of the audio/graphical settings at all
- Not possible to remap keys
- Should have included a level editor really

= A decent game well worth the price which will give you something to do before the next Hitman."

reviewText: This would rate as the first game I've bought from Steam that I've requested a refund for.  And I've bought some sh*tty games.\n\nSuffice it to say that this is like a board game, you maneuver the Hitman around the board, attacking other pieces from behind or from the side.  When you attack" a piece
date: it gets flung off the board like a chess piece.  It was cool like the first time.\n\nI guess there's a kind of caveat emptor that comes into play when purchasing Steam products.  And ultimately it's on me to make sure that I research the game that I am intending to purchase.  I made a poor assumption that this was turn-based in the vein of "Silent Storm"
recommended: where you could strategically maneuver the Hitman around and perform various actions like you can in the FPS.\n\nIt's nothing like this.  Essentially it's like a big game of "Sorry".  Only "Sorry" is at least fun when you're drunk and you can flick the pieces off the table and p*ss off your friends.  There is some strategy involved
hoursPlayed: and perhaps I could have tried it a little longer to truly get the feel.  But I was horribly disappointed in this game
voteText:
it was so much different than billed and expected.

What else to talk about?  You have to drag and drop the pieces with the mouse...which is pretty annoying.  My understanding is that it's a port from a mobile app.  But would it have been that hard to make the pieces easier to move?  There are only about four things you can do and moving the pieces is a big part of it.

The game boasts many "levels".  The first "level" (1-1) involves you maneuvering the Hitman into the city sewer
helpfulPercent: two drags and you're "done".  You don't even get any decent graphics of the Hitman grappling with a manhole
votesHelpful: no cut-scenes of him clambering down.\n\nHonestly
votesTotal: I thought this was a pretty obvious money grab and attempt at squeezing some cash out of established fans.  I got news for you
votesFunny: Square Enix -- the Hitman franchise ain't all that fab any more and hasn't been any good for years.  Maybe try to go back to the original formula -- sneaking around and garroting people.\n\nDon't waste your money.  Or

reviewText: This game simply does not function on PC, at least for me.\n\nThe menu disappeared and reappeared whenever I moved my mouse and when it was visible it had controller buttons (I dont have a controller plugged in) instead of keyboard buttons so even if I could have interacted with the menu using my the keyboard I have no way to know what button I am supposed to press to get anything to happen. My keyboard doesnt have a yellow button labeled Y" and they didnt match that button to the actual "Y" on my keyboard so when I see a menu that says Options and has a yellow "Y" next to it I have absolutely no way of knowing what button they arbitrarily decided to map to yellow "Y"."

reviewText:
Decent and addictive puzzle game.
Hitman theme.
Nice graphics.
Sound isn't too annoying.
Hitman theme works.

Progressive difficulty through obstacles and new mechanics.
Not too challenging, but the multiple objectives mean you can get more out of each puzzle.

Works well with the controller or a graphics tablet. Mouse is ok, but it's a lot of click-dragging.
Using the controller changes the icons to Xbox icons. They don't look good - the mouse icons are better.

There are a lot of levels and I would like to do them all. £5 for probably 15-20 hours of gameplay is a nice price per hour.

It is a lot better new hitman coming out" companion than the sniper challenge that was a few years ago...
Got bored of that in about 15 minutes.

Having played the leaked alpha of hte new hitman game
date: I think the new hitman will be a bit better than the last one
recommended: so maybe this side-game is a sign that things are getting better for agent 47 - BUT ON PC DAMMIT

reviewText:
Hitman GO snuck onto PC and threw me off. I had heard of the game, but never actually considered playing it. After watching the trailer and looking at screenshots I had to give it a shot.

Here's the rundown:
Hitman GO basically acts as a virtual board game (I have no idea if it is real but whatevs)
You play as Agent 47 and you must strategize to reach the exit of each level without getting spotted. If you're spotted, you start from the beginning. The game is real fun and at some points, it's nerve-rackingly difficult.
Once you beat said difficult level, you will feel like you accomplished something or say man
date:
how did I not figure that out?!"
It's one of the most puzzling games I've played but it's so damn good. It has a lot of content for a game that's only $6.39. I'd advise anyone to get it while it's that cheap because it's a very nice game. I personally love it and can't stop playing it.

I rate it 8.5/10"

reviewText: Think of this like a game of chess, where to move, at what time, subsequent moves etc. But instead of a medieval name pieces, you a one badass bald dude who can just kill at the click of a button. It is a mobile game port to PC, but done right!

reviewText:
Pros
*Simple.
*Interesting concept.

Cons
*Graphics are at best 'basic'.
*No unique ways to beat the level / challanges are virtually all the same i.e. get breifcase, get to end of level in x many moves.  The developers could have added much more variety.

Verdict
A decent causal game, alternatively navigate round your neighbourhood in straight lines without making direct eye contact.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
It's a really neat puzzle game with levels of varying difficulty. Took me about 9 hours to do all the achievements (i.e. all objectives on all levels), and as I bought it during the launch sale it feels like good value, though I would love even more levels.

The port from tablet to pc is well made, as far as I can tell. I've played it both using the mouse and using a touch screen (and stylus), and I think the mouse worked slightly better although both methods of input work well.

Should Squeenix ever decide to make a real board game out of Hitman using mechanics similar to this, I'd definitely consider getting that.

reviewText: FACT: 99% of all mobile games exist just to drain your wallet. I have found only three exceptions to this on my phone travels. A FMV game called Tender Loving Care". A point and click game called "Yesterday". And this game
date:
HITMAN GO.

Hitman GO is a minimalist puzzle game take on the complex hitman series.  It prides itself on boiling down all the complexness of bloodmoney into a simple yet challenging puzzle game (Which is better then it sounds trust me) Enough talk lets assasinate some ♥♥♥♥♥es and dive right in to HITMAN GO!

STORY
While the other Hitman Games had a rich story as the cherry on top of tight gameplay
recommended:
HITMAN GO has no story and doesnt really need one. Your a hitman. Kill your way to the exit of each level. Sometimes the level exit is replaced with a random guy you need to kill. No Big Deal.

PRESENTATION
The graphics arent HYPEREALISTIC 1020P HD However. The minamalist board game style is not only really nice and easy on the eyes but also isnt distracting when you are trying to play. Even though the layout is simple you still feel like your sneaking around a airport or a suburban apartment complex. The game is usualy silent to help you concintrate
hoursPlayed:
but the smoothe sounds of Ave Maria kick in in the levels where you kill your target. Which usualy calms you down from rage quitting.

GAMEPLAY
There are currently 5 chapters with two half chapters inspired by some of the other Hitman Games. All in All 91 levels with scaling difficulty. When you start out
voteText: its very simple. Get to the end of the level
votesHelpful: attack gaurds from behind. But more and more gameplay elements get thrown in as you proceed such as everything from guns to gaurds with dogs and tazers. Mixing all these elements in with old things you learn is great at keeping you on your toes and makes for a great puzzle experience. There are also two alternate objectives for each level which requires you to finish the level whilst also doing something
votesTotal:
like picking up a breifcase or killing everyone. Making a bit of replay-ability.

FREEMIUM ASPECTS
In the mobile version  the only micro transactions were to pay for walkthroughs or "hints" if you got stuck on a level. This was great because it encouraged the player to get better and find the solution themselves. In the steam version
votesFunny: there are no micro transactions at all
commentsCount:
so cheat to your hearts content! WARNING IF YOU USE THE INGAME HINTS YOU WILL NOT GET A ACHIEVMENT!

Ranking: FULL PRICE BUY
"

reviewText: Hitman GO: Definitive Edition is more of a puzzle/strategy type of game instead of it being a action/third person shooter game. You'll definitely have to use your brain and strategize on how to defeat the levels and the enemies. If you are having a hard time completing a level, you can use the hint system in order to suceed and figure out what mistake you've made. All in all, this game isn't bad at all especially for a game that is made for the app store. The only thing I have against this game is that the achievements on this game are a little buggy (Some levels don't activate the achievements and other levels do. It's really strange and weird.) I definitely recommend this game but buy this game when it's on sale!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I was captivated by the pleasing aesthetic of this game, and it held my interest for a lot longer than many other puzzle games with similar gameplay. It's the first game in a looooong time that made me feel compelled to hunt down all of the achievements. Clocking in at about 8 hours worth of gameplay, I definitely feel like I got my 8 dollars worth of enjoyment. Some people may want to hold off for a sale, however. Anyone who rags on this game's control scheme for making you click and drag your Hitman around the board is clearly missing the point on what the developers were trying to accomplish with the stylization of this game.\n\nI definitely recommend this game if you're a fan of puzzle games, even if you're like me, and have yet to play another other game in the Hitman franchise.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: This is a fun game, simple to play but kind of difficult to master (especially if you like getting 3/3 on each board). I won't lie I've used the internet for some of them but I've enjoyed it. a fun time-waster with the Hitman series. If you like a slow pace puzzle-ish game, this is a good start
